div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
TERMS OF ANGLO-JAPANESE AGREEMENT. JAPAN’S RIGHT OF CONTROL IN KOREA. ENGLAND’S RIGHT TO SAFEGUARD INDIA. THE EVENT OF ANOTHER RUSSO-JAPANESE WAR
div.p: London, September 26. The text of the Anglo-Japanese agreement has been published here and at Tokio. It con- twins a preamble uni eight articles. The preamble states that the object of the agree meant is the consolidation and the maintenance of general peace in Eastern Asia and India and the preservation of the common interests of all the powers in China, by insuring the independence and integrity of that country on the principal of the open door, and the main- tenence of the territorial rights of Great Britain and Japan in Eastern Asia and India, and the defence of their special interests therein.

Article 1 stipulates that whenever the rights and interests of either party are jeopar- dised the governments shall communicate with each other fairly, and frankly consider jointly the measures to be taken to safeguard them.

Article II. provides that if by reason of an unprovoked attack or aggressive action, wher- ever arising, on the part of any power or powers either party be involved in war in defence of its territorial rights and interests, the other party will at once come to the assist- ance of its ally, and will conduct the war in common and make peace in mutual agreement.

Article III states that as Japan possesses paramount political, military, and economic rights in Korea, Great Britain recognises her right to take such measures for the guidance, control, and protection of Korea as she may deem to be a proper and necessary safeguard to advance those interests, provided that such measures do not contrary to the principle of equal commercial opportunities for all.
Article IV. states that Japan recognises the rights of Great Britain to take such measures in the proximity of the Indian frontier as may be necessary to safeguard her Indian posses- sions.
Article V. provides tint both parties agree that neither will, without consulting the other, enter into separate arrangements with another to the prejudice of the objects specified in the preamble.

Article VI. refers to the event of a Russo- Japanese war, and in such case Great Britain undertakes to maintain a strict neutrality, and to come to the assistance of Japan in the event of attack by another power.

Article VII. stipulates that the conditions under which armed assistance will be rendered shall be arranged by the Naval and Military authorities of the parties, who shall consult one another freely from time to time.
Article VIII. states that the term of the present agreement is 10 years, but it may be terminated by either party by a year’s notice to that effect. (Reuter)

London, September 26. A letter from Lord Lansdowne dated 6th inst. insructs Sir C. Hardinge to comunicate the treaty to the Russian Government, and explains that the treaty which was signed on the 12th of August has not been published hitherto with a view to the peace negotiations. He trusts that the Russian Government will recognize the fact that the new agreement is an international instrument which will be to the advantage of all powers interested in the affairs of the Far East.
Lord Lansdowne has made au identical communication to France. (Reuter)

London, September 27. Correction. Article VIII. stipulates that the agreement shall last ten years. If neither party denounce it at the end of the ninth year it will remain in force until the expiration of one year from the date upon which either has denounced it, but it will continue to be bind- ing ipso facto if either shall be engaged in war at such date of expiration. (Reuter

Paris, September 27. The signature of the Franco German agree rnent regarding Morocco has been postponed, pending the final revision. It is stated that Germany has recognised the special rights for which France has contended. (Reuter

div.head: AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY
div.p: Budapest, September 27. The Emperor’s refusal to listen to any changes in the Hungarian army has united all parties in Hungary against the Crown. The leaders of the coalition have issued a manifesto denouncing the Soverign’s attempt to cripple the nation's control over its own affairs. (R.)

div.head: DISASTROUS TYPHOON AT MANILA
div.p: Manila, September 27. A typhoon here has killed 10 natives and wounded 500. A thousand are homeless, and damage to the extent of £100,000 has been done. (Reuter

div.head: A SECOND PEACH CONFERENCE
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 27. Russia has invited the Powers to another conference at the Hagna. (Havas

div.head: H.H. THE KHEDIVE. KHEDIVE’S VISIT TO CONSTANTINOPLE
div.p: Constantinople September 27. H.H. the Khedive is leaving Constantinople with his mother, expressed his satisfaction at the warm reception extended to him by the Sultan. (Havas)

div.head: ARRIVAL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The steamer Dalmatia which had been chartered by H.H. the Khedive for his journey from Constantinople to Alexandria arrived at 2 a.m. this morning. A guard of honor com- posed of the Quay Police had been stationed all night at the harbour to keep order and paraded as soos as the approach of the Dal- matia was signalled. The Government offices and steamers in the harbour flew the Egyptian flag. At 6 am. a special launch conveyed the Khodive to Ras el Tin palace, where the Mi- nisters, the Governor of Alexandria, and the Princes of the Khedivial family awaited his arrival. As he stopped on shore a salute of 21 guns greeted his return to Egyptian soil and the Princes and Ministers hastened to pay the courtesias and utter the greetings usual on such occasions. At 7.40 a.m. the Khedivah and the young princes and princesses with a large suite left for the Montazah Palace, H.H. the Khedive remaining for the time at Ros et Tin.

div.head: NORTH EGYPT LAND COMPANY LIMITED
div.p: We are authorized by the Board of Di- rectors in London to state that this Company has completed the whole of the preliminaries and that all the preparatory work is now a "fait accompli”. The London Directors are making arrangements for the payments to be made in order to complete the acquisition of the pro- perties purchased from the Daira Khassa of H. H. the Khedive and the measuring of the lands and the preparation of the first season’s cultivation is being proceeded with at once.

This well known agricultural engineer, M. N. Alchevsky, has just left London for Alexandria for the special object of putting the work in hand as set out in the reports of Sir Douglas Fox and Partners.

We understand that the support of a vary important and influential group in Paris has been obtained, and that this group has taken a large interest in the Company and that we shall shortly see the shares quoted on the Paris Bourse as well as on the London Stock Exchange.

We have it on the same authority that the Daira Khassa of H.H. the Khedive has obtain- ed the nomination of its representative on the Board of the Company in consequence of the large interest which the Daira Khassa has secured in the Company.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p: Official intimation has been received at Cairo and Khartoum from the War Office in London that in future the British troops sta- tioned at the latter place will be under the command and immediate orders of the Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan and not as hitherto of the General officer commanding in Egypt. This change has been decided upon on the recommendation of Sir Reginald Wingate and with the entire concurrence and approval of Lord Cromer.

The statement published on Tuesday by a Cairo contemporary that it is intended to gradually augment the British garrison of the Suiluu as that country develops and its trade improves, is incorrect. We learn from the highest authority that the recent decision of the house authorities to maintain the force stationed in this country at its present strength will be strictly adhered to and in future one infantry regiment and a detachment of the Royal Army Medics Corps will, as heretofore, be quartered at Khartoum.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Tuscan Prince, from Manchester, left Malta yesterday with passengers and general cargo and is duo to arrive at Alex- andria on Sunday.
The Mosa line Maeris sailed from Glasgow yesterday morning and is due at Alexandria on the 12th October.
The Messageries, Maritimes road boat Portu- gal, which left Alexandria last Friday, arrived at Marreilles yesterday morning.

The Russian Steam Navigation Company’s mail boat Tehatchoff will leave Alexandria on Wednesday next for Odessa, calling at Piaens, Snyrna, the Dardanel’es, and con- necting with the same companies mail boats for Sevastapool, the Anatolian, Carasian, Crimean and Sea of Arov ports.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: All Saint’s Church, Cairo—On and after Sunday next October 1 the Holy Communion will be celebrated at All Saint’s Church, Cairo at 8.30 a.m. instead of at 8 and the morning service will begin at 10.30 a.m instead of at 9.30.

Church of Scotland Schools.-Two new teachers have been appointed to reinforce the staff of the Scottish Schools. Mr. Wm. Thom from Aberdeen has already arrived and Mr. Maurice Goodrick from Great Yarmouth will arrivo early in October. Fall particulars will be seen in our advertisement in another column.

Port Sudan.—A special commission will assemble during November to consider the various matters in connection with the disposal and allotment of land for building purposes at Port Sudan. The recommendations of the commission will afterwards be submitted to the Governor General at Khartoum for his final decision.

San Stefano Casino —Tho charity per- formance to be held at the San Stefano Casino to-morrow afternoon in aid of the Calabrian sufferers promisee to be most brilliant. The organisers. H E. Khalil Hamdi Pasha Hamada and the San Stefano Club are doing their utmost to provide an excellent programme and to judge from the items, which we published yesterday, their efforts will meet with great success.

Suicide of an Officer — Ahmed Effeudi Khoury, an officer of the 10th battalion. Egyp- tian Army, died on Monday from a self-inflicted bullet wound in the abdomen. He left a letter to his mother leaving her all his money after payment of hi*s outstanding debts. The occur- ence was rendered more tragic by the fact that the deceased officer was about to be married. Tho motive for the act is absolutely unknown.

To aid the Calabrians—A special news- paper will be published on Sunday by the International Society for tho Help of Persons Suffering from Accidents,appealing to the residents of this town to give generously to the relief fund for the victims of the Calabrian earthquake. The appeal will be made in five different languages, Arabic, English, French Italian, and Greek, and this publication will, we imagine, be unique.

Anglo-Egyptian Bank—We are informed that the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd., will open an Agency at Mansourah on October 2. The officers of the new agency are situated in the main street quite close to the rail- way station. BP's will be discounted and foreign exchange given, in fact banking business of all sorts will be carried on by the branch, the establishment of which is welcomed by the inhabitants of Mansourah and the neighbourhood. Mr. C. E. Green will manage the now agency.

New Military Buildings in Cairo. — A confrere stated recently that the War Office proposed to dispose of the military school and the barracks behind it at Abbassiah and the adjoining land and with the proceeds of the sale to erect now new buildings beyond tho Polygon. Tho true facts of the case are that the military authorities have decided upon building a new school and barracks for the infantry battalions stationed at Abbassieh, as they consider the present old buildings not worth repairing, but they are awaiting the necessary grant from the Ministry of Finance who will then dispose of the present buildings as it deems best.

British Chamber of Commerce.—We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appoint- ing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain farther particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: THE CHATHAM EXPLOSION. SUCCESSFULLY PERFORMED. STATE TELEGRAPHS BREAK DOWN. (From our Correspondent.)
div.p: (By Telegraph). Port Said, Thursday 8.48 a.m. Mr. Harris and his assistants commenced fixing the firing charger in the holds of the Chatham at six o'clock this morning and it a expect that all will be ready for the explosion by nine o’clock. The "all ready’ signal, how- ever, has not yet been given though it is ex- pected at any moment and excited crowds are watching the offices of the Suer Canal Com- pany. The state telegraph lines have not been out as it is hoped that they may escape damage. A large number of special correspon- dents, representing both the Egyptian and foreign Press, left for Ras el Esh by special train at eight o’clock.

div.head: {By Telegraph)
div.p: Thursday, 10.23 a.m. The explosion of the Chatham took place at 9.58 a.m. I took up my position on the roof of the Eastern Exchange Hotel as being the most suitable site, from which to view the explosion and that I might be able to wire you the result without delay. I am, therefore, unable to go into details but will wire you fully at the earliest possible moment.

The great event has passed successfully but I cannot say to what extent the mari- time and fresh water canals have been dam- aged. The lines of the State Telegraphs have been broken and messages are being sent via the cable of theEastern Telegraph Company.

As for the explosion, from my position it appeared as if a vast colnmn of grey smoke, shaped like a gigantic tree, was rushing up- wards with great rapidity. No earth tremor was perceptible and the surface of the water in the harbour and in the canal all along the stretch visible from here was not disturbed in the slightest degree.

Had we not been waiting in feverish excite- ment and expecting one knew not what, the explosion would have in all probability passed unnoticed. The tradesmen, of the town, who had closed their shops in many instances, were greatly surprised, as were indeed all those who had remained in Port Said, and perhaps a little disappointed that some damage was not done to a few windows.

div.head: (From our Cairo Correspondent) (By Telephone)
div.p: A telegram has just been received from lamailia stating that shortly before 10 a.m. the sound of the explosion was very distictly heard at lamailia 25 miles from Ras-el-Esh.

div.head: STOP PRESS EDITION (By Telegraph).
div.p: Port Said 1.36 p.m. The explosion has been a great success. The fore part of the ship has been blown away as far as the fore engine room. There are now twenty-two metres of water underneath the explosive magazine. The canal is now only five metres deep in the middle, the average depth of water having been nice metres before explosion. The charge was fired from kilometre 12 by Mr. Harris. Seven observers were watching from this point, the remainder waiting at kilometer 8. Fearful damage was done to the Asiatic shore, a ritt 50 feet long being blown in the east bunk. No damage was done to the African back. The rails have not been disturbed. The Canal telegraph wires have been destroy- ed. The State wires will be repaired by 3 p.m. The fresh water canal is uninjured. Showers of debris fa11 in the circle of 600 yards radius, Beams, rails, fragments of the engines, and plates were hurled everywhere. Thousands of fish were killed. Repair gangs are on the spot It is hoped that the dual will be dear in seven days.

div.head: Port Said, Tuesday.
div.p: To-day’s operations at kilometre 19 were, from all I hear, decidedly interesting. Mr. Harris in company with his assistants and the chief electrician of the Canal Company were to be been at the railway station at an early hour making enquiries fur special materials which had been rent from Alexandria. The party, after having procured some special instruments for testing electric currents from the electric light station, proceeded to the Canal office where Mr. Tillier held a short consulta- tion with Mr. Harris, after which, he and his party proceeded in the Albatross down the canal and took with them cables, wires, and a quantity of other material for the tests which it was proposed to carry through to-day. The party arrived at Ras el Esh where a gang was awaiting the arrival of the explosives train which had attached to it a powder waggon holding twenty oases of high explosives, all of exactly the same type ad is to be found in the bold of the unfortunate Chatham, viz red dynamite and blasting gelatine. In the waggon were also rolls of new submarine cable and a considerable quantity of other necessary mater- ial for the monster explosion.

The experts then proceeded to test the wires and batteries, of which there were severed, the principal being a twist exploder of the very latest type with which quite a number marine detonators were fired.Test followed test; long and short cables in fact every imaginable trial was made, many of a most severe character, the idea being that there should not be the slightest chance of any hitch occurring on Thursday. I understand that after some hours of these trials of every possible combination, Mr. Harris declared himself satisfied in everv way. and he is un- doubtedly of the opinion that things will go smoothly at the proper time. The power of this twist exploder is stupendous, registering a number of empires such as is not indicated on the newest and beat devised of voltameter- which Mr. Harris used in his trials. The voltage also is large but, from what I know of the matter, I believe that it is not voltage - which is of such paramount importance but volume, which quality is only indicated by the number of amperes a battery registers when actually delivering its electric force. The detonators to be used in the explosion are of the most recent manufacture and are construct- ed purely and simply for submarine work. The detonating charge is enclosed within a brass tube, which in its turn is covered with thick layers of guttapercha and tape. The firing shock is delivered along two copper wires which terminate in the interior of the fuse in a small platino-iridium bridge. The action of these fuses is simple ; the current of sui- able volume being delivered along the wires from the battery heats the bridge in a moment, the bridge at once glows, and, in so doing, fires the charge of fulminate of mercury contained in the brass tube. This shook being commun- icated to the mine in which the fuse is placed, causes the material of the mine to explode. After firing quite a number of detonators the party returned to the Ras el Esh station and eventually arrived at Port Said at a late hour.

The explosives which arrived at kilometre 14 at about 2 p.m. were carefully transported across the canal to the Asiatio bank and there covered up and left properly guarded. They will remain there until to morrow, when Mr. Harris proposes to prepare the mines for the great event.

div.head: Wednesday.
div.p: The Canal Company’s steam launch was early at work again to-day taking M. Tillier, the Chef da Transit, and Mr. Harris’ party down the canal, so that they might make all final arrangements, and prepare the firing charges before dark, for to-morrow morning. During the day the telegraph staff were- busy clearing all the wires which are to be used to-morrow and n umbers of men were putting the final touches to the other prepara- tions, notably those connected with the fresh water canal and railway.

A considerable number of rails have been accumulated at kilometres 14 and 24 in readiness to proceed at once with the repairs which may be necessary after the explosion, and gangs of railway men were being instruct- ed in their duties so that there might be as little delay as possible when the time comes for action.

Mr. Harris and his staff prooceeded to the wreak early in the morning and passed a final inspection, making several slight modi- fications in the arrangements with a view to having things straight and clear before the fixing of the mines took place.

Ten cases of explosives were handled, their contents being emptied into canvas bags which were made on the spot and were afterwards sown up. There are two mines; the larger one of 3001bs. of blasting gelatine and dynamite is intended for the magazine of the vessel, and the smaller charge, mode np in exactly the same way of 200 lbs. of similar material, is to go into No. 3 hold.

The wires being made and the detonator having been connected to their respective charges, tea wires which are to traverse the canal from the telephone cables on the west bank, were attached and the joints most care- fully made. After this a length of cable equal to the distance between the two holds was connected to the charges and all was declared ready.
The wires were stowed away and locked up on board a dahabesh ; the batteries were ins- pected ; and the party returned to Port Said after a most tiring day.

div.head: Wednesday, Later.
div.p: At 5 am. to-morrow the launch will leave Port Said with Mr. Harris and party and several of the Canal Company’s chiefs. It will then proceed at once to place the mines, and make final connections aided by divers and a large staff of telegraph line workers in charge of Mr. Plum. The detachment of sol- diers will take up their positions at five kilo- metres radius from the wreck. The police will form a cordon at Rasowa to prevent an exodus of Port Said residents. No one will be allowed to go to Ras el Esh except officials of the Canal Company. All the wires are to be cut on Wednesday night and Mr. Harris expects to have all ready by 7.30 a.m.
All messages will be conveyed from and to officials stationed at different points by mount- ed men.

At 8 a.m. a signal will be hoisted on the flagstaff of the Canal Company's offices. At 9 a.m. the current will be closed and the greatest explosion of dynamite which the world has ever known will take place, Mr. Harris firing the battery at Bas el Esh. The folowing will be stationed at the generative stations—
M, M. Tillier, Doyen, Rsynaud, Smith, Percier, Jusserand, Coulloun, Lord Ed. Cecil, and six or seven other offinals, Mr. Harris and assistants.
No one else wUl be allowed there, but a few photographers will be permitted to «‘ation themselves at kilometre 13.6.

div.head: CHURCH OF SCOTLAND.
div.p: SESSION- 1905-1906. THe BOYS’ SCHOOLS Re-open Monday, 2nd October. THI GIRLS SCHOOLS Re open Wednesday, 4th October.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB. REGATTA.
div.p: The following is the result of yesterday's regatta :— Class I. Boat Start Finish Sailed by 1 Sans Pareille 8.60.09 5.19.03 H. Tsehodi 2 Leman 8.40.10 A24.22 3 Tier-el-Mina 3.32.15 5.28.10 Celtic 8.88.30 5.81.55 Major Gamble Minnie 3.42.45 5 34.57 Coot 8.88.29 gave up
Class II 1 Calypso 4.07.18 5.44 50 a Wacom 2 Maar 4.04.85 5.45.40 P. Ott 8 Akraba 8.52.52 5.47.50 Sagh. Phillipe Tan tab 4 00.40 6.50 80 C. Jessica 8.52.25 6A6.05 Grafton Bey
The wind was very light from N.W. leering round to the N. during the latter past of the afternoon and almost died away altogether.

The Akraba on the port tank was unfortuna- tely caught by the Calypso on the starboard tack, close to the finishing line and the Calypso pushing her advantage, the Akraba had to give way. Again when the Akraba had manag- ed to get away back on the port take the Masr came along on the starboard tank and forced here to give way again ; this was all pretty manoeuvring riewed by the spectators but was greatly to the disadvantage of the Akraba which however came in third.
The following is the soon of points gained during the month.

div.head: ESBEKIAH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut-Colonel R.Q.C. Cox commanding, and officers, 2nd Royal In- nsakilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme of music by quasi request in the Esbekieh Gardens tomorrow (Friday) evening, commencing at 9 am.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lady Cromer does not retain to Cairo with the Earl of Cromer next month, but will come out in November.
Sir Rudolf von Slatin Pasha is expected to arrive on Monday next by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat.
Mr. Frank Western, A.R.S.M, M-Inst.- M. M. managing engineer to the Mines Exploration Company, returns to Egypt at the end of the present month.

Mr. Percy Parks-Smith, Stud. Inst MM. Mr. A.M. Hogartha, A.RS.M., Stud. Inst. M. M., and Mr. Percy C. Whitehead, Stud. Inst. M.M, assistant engineers in the service of the Egyptian Mines Exploration Company, will leave for Egypt on October 4th.

Mr. Stanley C. Dunn, A.R.S.M., Stud. Inst M.M , and Mr. Hubert Roose, A.R.8.M., Stud. Inst M M , have bean appointed by Mr. C-J. Alford, to examine a prospecting area in the Sudan which has been granted to the Victoria Investment Corporation, and leave for Khar- toum on October 11th.
Amongst the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel ; Port Said, we notice :—

Mr. W. McQueen, Mr. C. Jarrat Mitohel Bey, Mme Mile Asti, Mr. A.L Llsyd, Mr. R.J. Johnstone, Mr. RM. Board, Mr. M. Spears, Mr. J.l. Carver, Mr. and Mrs. Master K 6. Mioklam, Mr.-G.E. Fletcher, Mr. Diacooo, Mr. C. Kaak, Mr. J.R Halbert, Mr. and R. Hibbert, Mr. H.R Brian, Mr. H.W. Maokay, Mr. H. Mardon, Mr. T. Bajocohi, Mr. L. Iconomopoulos, Mr.JS.J. Ssonel Hr.’Jf. Hamil- ton, Mr. A. Caroelli, Mr. Longworth.
